articles.headline: Two Parties, Two Distinct Paths to the Nomination
articles.snippet: The Democrats are facing a long nomination battle; Republicans are closer to rallying around a nominee.
articles.abstract: The Democrats are facing a long nomination battle; Republicans are closer to rallying around a nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Republican and Democratic presidential contests began diverging Tuesday, leaving the Democrats facing a long and potentially divisive nomination battle and the Republicans closer to an opportunity to put aside deep internal divisions and rally around a nominee.

articles.headline: Papers Show Wachovia Knew of Thefts
articles.snippet: The bank solicited business from companies it knew had been accused of telemarketing crimes, documents show.
articles.abstract: The bank solicited business from companies it knew had been accused of telemarketing crimes, documents show.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last spring, Wachovia bank was accused in a lawsuit of allowing fraudulent telemarketers to use the bank’s accounts to steal millions of dollars from unsuspecting victims. When asked about the suit, bank executives said they had been unaware of the thefts.

articles.headline: McCain Gains Wide Support; Huckabee Wins in States in South
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain was successful in the delegate-rich states, while Mike Huckabee racked up victories across the South.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain was successful in the delegate-rich states, while Mike Huckabee racked up victories across the South.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain of Arizona won the most states and appeared poised to win the most delegates on Tuesday with impressive primary victories in the delegate-rich states of California, New York and Illinois. Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor, revived his candidacy with victories across the South.

articles.headline: Luck and Defiance Rescued Limping McCain Campaign
articles.snippet: John McCain's strong performance on Tuesday is only the latest part of one of the most remarkable resurrection stories in recent American politics.
articles.abstract: John McCain's strong performance on Tuesday is only the latest part of one of the most remarkable resurrection stories in recent American politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a Friday morning last July, Senator John McCain packed a carry-on bag, boarded a cheap flight out of Baltimore and traveled alone to New Hampshire.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Bottom Line for (Red)
articles.snippet: The “Red” campaign launched a year ago by rock star Bono has generated more than $22 million to fight H.I.V. and AIDS in Rwanda, but critics say not enough money is getting to clinics.
articles.abstract: The “Red” campaign launched a year ago by rock star Bono has generated more than $22 million to fight H.I.V. and AIDS in Rwanda, but critics say not enough money is getting to clinics.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda  A year ago, staff members at the Treatment and Research AIDS Center could barely cope. Patients, unable to find care elsewhere, flowed in from every corner of the country. And if one of them was fortunate enough to find a bed here, she often had to share it.

articles.headline: Support Divided, Top Democrats Trade Victories
articles.snippet: Neither Barack Obama nor Hillary Rodham Clinton could secure an edge to the Democratic nomination.
articles.abstract: Neither Barack Obama nor Hillary Rodham Clinton could secure an edge to the Democratic nomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama carved up the nation in the 22-state nominating contest on Tuesday, leaving the Democratic presidential nomination more elusive than ever. Mrs. Clinton won California, Massachusetts, New Jersey and her home state, New York, while Mr. Obama took Connecticut, Georgia, Minnesota and his base in Illinois.

articles.headline: Microsoft Adversary Rises Instinctively at Yahoo Bid
articles.snippet: Whatever the outcome of Microsoft’s bid for Yahoo, the move and Google’s countermoves mark  an escalation in the confrontation between the two companies.
articles.abstract: Whatever the outcome of Microsoft’s bid for Yahoo, the move and Google’s countermoves mark  an escalation in the confrontation between the two companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, Andrew S. Grove, then the chief executive of Intel, aptly described the hypercompetitive mentality of Silicon Valley in his book title “Only the Paranoid Survive.”

articles.headline: In CBS Test, Mobile Ads Find Users
articles.snippet: CBS plans to announce on Wednesday that it is trying one of the first serious experiments with cellphone advertising that is customized for a person’s location.
articles.abstract: CBS plans to announce on Wednesday that it is trying one of the first serious experiments with cellphone advertising that is customized for a person’s location.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pssst, hey you! There’s a cheap latte waiting at the coffee shop on the corner!

articles.headline: Northeast Delivers 2 Big Prizes for Clinton
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton scored twin victories in the Democratic primaries in her home state of New York and in New Jersey. In Connecticut, Senator Barack Obama won by a small margin.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton scored twin victories in the Democratic primaries in her home state of New York and in New Jersey. In Connecticut, Senator Barack Obama won by a small margin.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton scored twin victories in the Democratic primaries in her home state of New York and in New Jersey on Tuesday. But her rival for the nomination, Senator Barack Obama, won by a narrow margin in Connecticut, a state she once expected to win easily.

articles.headline: Dow Plunges on Survey of Business
articles.snippet: Stocks plummeted after a business survey provided another strong signal that the United States might be in the early stages of a recession.
articles.abstract: Stocks plummeted after a business survey provided another strong signal that the United States might be in the early stages of a recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks plummeted on Wall Street on Tuesday after a business survey provided another strong signal that the United States might be in the early stages of a recession. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 370 points as the market experienced its worst day in nearly a year.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Floyd Norris
